item.description: Oil held recent declines with the focus on how much OPEC+ will increase production at a meeting on Sunday.

Saudi Arabia is seeking to transform its crude-dependent economy by developing new industries, and is pushing into petrochemicals as a way to earn more from its energy deposits.

item.title: Asia Set for Cautious Open as Tariff Nerves Linger: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian stocks are poised for a cautious open as investors weigh the buoyant mood on Wall Street with lingering concerns over the global impact of President Donald Trump’s tariff agenda.
item.dc:creator: Jason Scott

item.title: US Treasuries Get Vote of Confidence From Korea’s Wealth Fund
item.description: South Korea’s $206.5 billion sovereign wealth fund is standing by US Treasuries as a core holding, undeterred by recent market volatility.
item.dc:creator: David Ingles, Haram Lim, Jaehyun Eom

item.title: Struggling Semiconductor Firm Wolfspeed Files for Bankruptcy
item.description: Wolfspeed Inc., a chipmaker caught in President Donald Trump’s push to reshape Biden-era tech subsidies, filed bankruptcy to enact a creditor-backed plan to slash $4.6 billion in debt.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Randles, Steven Church

item.title: Dollar Index Slumps 10.8% in Biggest First-Half Loss Since 1973
item.description: The US dollar index tumbled in the first six months of the year, posting its worst first-half performance since 1973 when Richard Nixon was president.
item.dc:creator: George Lei, Carter Johnson

item.title: Lagarde Says ECB’s New Strategy Fixes ‘False Certainty’
item.description: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde says the central bank’s new strategy will allow policymakers to deliver more nuanced communication at the ECB’s annual central-banking forum in Sintra, Portugal.

item.title: US to Resume Mexican Livestock Imports in Phases After Halt
item.description: The US will start reopening ports to Mexican livestock in phases, after trade along the southern border had been halted in May by the spread of a parasitic fly.
item.dc:creator: Ilena Peng

media:content.media:description: Empty corrals at the Union Ganadera Chihuahua cattle import facility in Santa Teresa, New Mexico, US, on Friday, June 20, 2025. The US Department of Agriculture announced a plan to open an $8.5 million facility in South Texas to combat the spread of the New World screwworm, a flesh-eating bug that is deadly to cattle.

item.title: Milei Suffers Legal Blow in Burford’s $16 Billion YPF Case
item.description: Argentina was ordered to give up its controlling stake in energy company YPF SA within two weeks to help satisfy a $16 billion US court judgment, a setback to President Javier Milei ahead of crucial midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris, Jonathan Gilbert, Kevin Simauchi

media:content.media:description: A YPF SA storage terminal in Ushuaia, Tierra del Fuego, Argentina, on Saturday, Sept. 7, 2024. The island province of Tierra del Fuego is Argentina’s electronics base thanks to a quirk of history. Islanders’ natural resilience is being severely tested by the president’s economic policies.

item.title: Codelco Sticks to SQM Lithium Deadline as Opposition Mounts
item.description: State-owned Codelco is on track to finalize a landmark deal with lithium supplier SQM well before the next Chilean government takes office, despite mounting political opposition heading into elections.
item.dc:creator: James Attwood

media:content.media:description: Brine pools at the Sociedad Quimica y Minera de Chile (SQM) chemical plant in Antofagasta, Chile, on Thursday, March 14, 2024. After a spectacular bust, battery-metal lithium is showing tentative signs of life on speculation the retracement that convulsed the market last year has forced the conditions for a recovery.

item.title: Apple May Use Outside AI to Power Siri in Major Reversal
item.description: Apple Inc. is considering using artificial intelligence technology from Anthropic PBC or OpenAI to power a new version of Siri, sidelining its own in-house models in a potentially blockbuster move aimed at turning around its flailing AI effort. The iPhone maker has talked with both companies about using their large language models for Siri, according to people familiar with the discussions. But no agreements have been reached. Bloomberg's Mark Gurman reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Lifts Syria Sanctions in Bid to Boost New Government
item.description: President Donald Trump signed an executive order terminating US sanctions on Syria, aiming to boost the nation’s struggling economy and support the new government after rebels overthrew President Bashar Al-Assad last year. The order removes various sanctions on Syria effective July 1 while keeping those on Assad, “his associates, human rights abusers, drug traffickers, persons linked to chemical weapons activities, ISIS or its affiliates, and Iranian proxies,” according to the White House. Trump’s move is part of an effort to “promote and support the country’s path to stability and peace,” White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt said Monday. “He’s committed to supporting a Syria that is stable, unified and at peace with itself and its neighbors.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: S&P 500 Climbs at End of Best Quarter Since 2023 | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Matt Miller. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: S&P 500 Climbs at End of Best Quarter Since 2023: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street’s bulls drove stocks to all-time highs at the end of a solid quarter amid hopes the US is moving closer to reaching concrete deals with its top trading partners. Bets the Federal Reserve will resume rate cuts powered the best first-half stretch for Treasuries in five years. The dollar saw its longest monthly slide since 2017.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: Treasuries Wrap Up Best Month Since February Ahead of Jobs Data
item.description: The Treasury market posted its best monthly performance since February, with traders focused on Thursday’s jobs report as a potential catalyst for further gains.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Ye Xie

item.title: Private Lenders Pitch Restructuring for Stressed Pallet Company
item.description: Private lenders have proposed a potential debt restructuring for 48Forty Solutions, less than a year after Summit Partners acquired a majority stake in the pallet management company, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Schneider, Olivia Fishlow

item.title: US Supreme Court to Take Up Controlling-Investor Challenges
item.description: The US Supreme Court will consider whether activist investors can use an 85-year-old law to challenge corporate moves bolstering controlling shareholders, in a case being closely watched by some of Wall Street’s biggest investment funds.
item.dc:creator: Jef Feeley, Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: Justices of the US Supreme Court during a formal group photograph at the Supreme Court in Washington, DC. Photographer: Eric Lee/Bloomberg

item.title: Robinhood Tokenizes US Company Shares for European Traders
item.description: Robinhood Markets Inc. is joining the growing push to trade US equities on the blockchain, making tokenized US securities available to 150,000 customers in 30 countries, 24 hours a day, five days a week.
item.dc:creator: Paige Smith, Jayna Rohslau

item.title: Nobody Would Blink' if Watergate Happened Today, Ed Price Says
item.description: Senior Fellow at New York University Ed Price joins Bloomberg Businessweek and discusses President Trump's hold over the American electorate, and the shifting of a new world order as the President signed an executive order “terminating the Syria sanctions program” in an effort to “support the country’s path to stability and peace,” according to the White House and the US Senate debates the tax bill.. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: S&P 500 Ends Quarter at Fresh Record on Trade-Talk Optimism
item.description: US stocks rose, closing at a fresh record as investors cheered progress in trade negotiations between the Trump administration and key partners as a tariff deadline nears.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Kniazhevich

media:content.media:description: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during the Voyager Technologies initial public offering (IPO) in New York, US, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. Voyager Technologies Inc. is seeking to raise as much as $319 million in an initial public offering, as it looks to capitalize on rising government spending on advanced defense technologies and space exploration.

item.title: ‘Crypto ETF Summer’ Kicks Off With New Blockchain-Powered Trade
item.description: Wall Street is about to get its first taste of a new kind of cryptocurrency product as the Trump administration eases the regulatory grip on the digital-asset industry.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Lee

item.title: Over a Third of US Population Uses GenAI
item.description: Generative artificial intelligence tools are being used by more than a third of the US population, and even more are interacting with it through search and customer service tools, explains eMarketer Principal Analyst Yory Wurmser. He joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Tech”. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Argentina Grew More Than Expected After Milei Lifts Controls
item.description: Argentina’s economy grew more than expected in April as President Javier Milei loosened some currency controls as part of a $20 billion agreement with the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: A customer pays with Argentine peso banknotes at a shop in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on Monday, April 14, 2025. Argentina reached a $20 billion agreement with the International Monetary Fund after President Javier Milei made sweeping changes to ease the nation's currency controls in a landmark moment for his government.

item.title: Tech Sector Impacted by Birthright Citizenship Ruling
item.description: Tech companies are the biggest employers of H-1B visa holders in the US. Erickson Immigration Group Partner Hiba Anver discusses how the US Supreme Court’s recent ruling related to birthright citizenship could impact those workers and the wider industry. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Should Apple Build a Smart Ring?
item.description: Bloomberg’s Mark Gurman discusses how Apple could expand its wearable offerings with a smart ring. He joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: More Than 5,000 Rent-Stabilized NYC Apartments Face a Funding Crunch
item.description: Funding to maintain thousands of rent-stabilized apartments in New York City owned by landlord Joel Wiener is in limbo after a federal judge denied a request to tap income belonging to its major lender, Flagstar Bank.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Randles

item.title: Trump Expands Fed Criticism Beyond Powell, Blames the Board
item.description: Trump Expands Fed Criticism Beyond Powell President Trump says Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell “and his entire Board, should be ashamed of themselves” for not lowering the federal funds rate. The social post comes after Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent played down speculation that President Donald Trump may consider an early move to nominate a successor to Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, pointing to one potential timeline that could see a name emerge in October or November. Bloomberg Treasury Reporter Dan Flatley reacts to the news. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Pimco's Schneider Sees Market Volatility Persisting
item.description: Jerome Schneider, Pimco managing director and head of short-term portfolio management and funding, says he expects core inflation to increase on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Falls as Mideast Tensions Ease Ahead of OPEC+ Decision
item.description: Oil edged down after its biggest weekly loss in two years as traders speculated on the volume of an expected OPEC+ supply hike and fears of Middle East tensions disrupting global oil flows dissipated.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Catherine Cartier

media:content.media:description: Flames burn off at an oil processing facility in Saudi Aramco's oilfield in the Rub' Al-Khali (Empty Quarter) desert in Shaybah, Saudi Arabia, on Tuesday, Oct. 2, 2018. Saudi Aramco aims to become a global refiner and chemical maker, seeking to profit from parts of the oil industry where demand is growing the fastest while also underpinning the kingdom’s economic diversification.

item.title: EU Said to Be Willing to Accept US Trade Deal With Key Exemptions
item.description: The European Union is willing to accept a trade arrangement with the US that includes a 10% universal tariff on many of its exports, but wants the US to commit to lower rates on key sectors. This is all according to people familiar with the matter. Europe wants lower levies on automobiles, car parts, steel and aluminum. The EU has until July 9 to secure a deal with President Donald Trump. Adam Farrar of Bloomberg Economics speaks on "Bloomberg Businessweek." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Musk Slams Trump Tax Bill, Again
item.description: Elon Musk has slammed the US Senate's version of President Donald Trump’s tax bill for cutting tax credits for electric vehicles. Bloomberg’s Max Chafkin talks about the impact that could have on Tesla with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)
